data.text: Contents
Roles and responsibilities – staffing and training .......................................................... 5
Purpose

To provide guidance and support to all relevant medical staff who are responsible for the care of patients with Cardiac Implantable Electronic Devices (CIED) in situ at the time of preparation for elective surgical procedures, both in the pre-assessment and surgical settings.

To provide clarity and direction regarding the process to be followed for the preparation of care for patients with CIEDs when being considered for and during elective surgical procedures, to ensure safe and effective care is provided.
Definition/background
The use of Cardiac Implantable Electronic Devices (CIEDs) for heart rhythm management includes:
Pacemakers for control of bradycardia (slow heart rates)
Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators (ICDs) for treatment of life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias (fast heart rates)
Biventricular or Resynchronisation Pacemakers/ICDs for treatment of heart failure using ventricular resynchronisation (CRT-P and CRT-D respectively)
Implantable Loop Recorders (ILRs) and Insertable Cardiac Monitors (ICMs) for monitoring cardiac arrhythmias

Despite already having a high degree of tolerance to electrical and magnetic interference fields, it is still possible for CIEDs to encounter problems if the energy level of a nearby field is very high, or has a frequency component that is close to that generated by the heart.
Possible effects on the function of the CIED include:
Inhibition of a pacemaker
Induction of fixed rate pacing
Software reset
Triggering of shocks in an ICD
Thermal heating at the lead/tissue interface
Inappropriate recording of interference as tachycardia episodes (ILR/ICM Only)

Electromagnetic interference (EMI) by most types of fields usually only interferes transiently with device function and when the interference ceases, the device returns to normal. Only very powerful fields are likely to have any permanent effects on device or lead function (e.g. gamma radiation or very strong magnetic fields).

Therefore, precautions need to be considered when procedures are carried out in which the patient may be exposed to electromagnetic interference (EMI). Failure to plan the management of these devices may lead to inappropriate device function and cause harm.
Scope
This clinical guidance applies to any patient who has a Cardiac Implantable Electronic Device (CIED) in situ and requires, or is being considered for, elective surgery.
Roles and responsibilities – staffing and training
The Preassessment Team are responsible for:
Being aware and compliant with this clinical guidance.
Ensuring the referring consultant/surgeon is aware that the patient has a CIED in situ and the patient is to be preassessed as appropriate.
Contacting the pacing/ICD clinic in the hospital in which the patient usually has their device followed up to request a copy of the last device follow up (including device details)
The Referring/Operating Consultant/Surgeon and Anaesthetist are responsible for:
Being aware and compliant with this clinical guidance, regardless of whether the elective procedure to be performed is under local or general anaesthesia.

Ensuring they have adequate and appropriate training and understanding of CIED's before requesting/making the decision that a patient's device may require reprogramming in order for the procedure to take place safely.

Ensuring that the preassessment team have contacted the patient's CIED follow up centre and obtained all the required information in order for them to be able to make a safe and informed decision regarding device management for the upcoming elective surgical procedure.
Ensuring that adequate information about the need and consequences for device reprogramming is communicated to the patient and/or family, and consent obtained.

Ensuring the Cardiac Physiology team is informed of the plan to reprogram the device. This can be done by completing the Device Reprogramming Request Form (Appendix 2), and returning it to the Cardiac Centre in a timely and appropriate manner.

Liaising with the Cardiac Physiology Team on the day of the elective surgical procedure regarding the reprogramming, including informing of any changes made to procedure date/time/location/procedural approach.
Ensuring they have adequate and appropriate training before using external defibrillation equipment in the event of an emergency.
Ensure the WHO checklist includes details of the patient's device and plan to reprogram.
Cardiac Physiologists deemed competent in the follow-up and management of CIEDs are required to:
Be aware and compliant with this clinical guidance.
Ensure they have the correct information about the device manufacturer, model and mode.

Ensure that the appropriate programmer is available for the date and time of the requested device reprogramming, and arranging for any additional support from device manufacturers if deemed necessary.
Ensure that any changes made to any device are recorded and evidenced fully on the appropriate Cardiology reporting system (Tomcat).
Ensuring that the operating team are aware of what programming changes have been made to the device in order for the procedure to take place safely.
Reiterating to the operating team on the day of the elective surgical procedure that the patient should be adequately monitored as in line with this guidance.
Clinical instruction – pre procedure (patient identification)
All patients for elective surgical procedures should be pre-assessed and CIED's in situ should be identified clearly on the TCI card when scheduling for any procedure.

All elective procedures to be performed on patients in which a CIED is in situ should be performed in normal working hours of the Cardiac Physiology Team , in order to all the availability of support should it be required.

All patients with a CIED in situ should be pre-assessed by an appropriately trained member of staff, regardless of whether the procedure is to be performed under Local or General Anaesthesia due to the clinical risk and preparation required.

The Anaesthetist/Consultant at pre-assessment should clarify the type of CIED in situ and assess the need for reprogramming (see Appendix 1 for guidance) in order to ensure the planned procedure can be carried out safely.

**Please do not assume that the patient is or is not pacemaker dependent where underlying rhythm is not clearly stated on the last follow up report. If you are unsure please seek advice from the Cardiac Physiologists (Extension 4185/4458/Cardiac Centre (A210) **
Considerations to be aware of when planning for elective surgical procedures in patients with CIEDs (Pacemakers/ICD):

Diathermy: Patients with CIEDs in situ are ideally treated with bipolar electrocautery. The short current pathway reduces the likelihood of current interfering with the device. Where monopolar must be used, the current pathway should be kept as short as possible by placing the return electrode as close to the surgical site as is possible, away from the location of the device. Electrocautery should be stopped immediately in the event of an arrhythmia.

Where diathermy/electrocautery is unavoidable, limit its use to short burst and ensure that the return electrode is anatomically positioned so that the current pathway between the diathermy electrode and return electrode is as far away from the CIED and leads as possible.

Harmonic Scalpels: The use of high frequency vibrations, as opposed to current being introduced to the body, poses very little risk to patients with CIEDs in situ. However, it is necessary that direct contact with the device is avoided at all costs. No device programming changes are advised when Harmonic Scalpels are to be used.
Considerations to be aware of when planning for elective surgical procedures in patients with CIEDs (ILR/ICM):
Implantable loop recorders (ILR) and Insertable Cardiac Monitors (ICM): only monitor the cardiac signals and therefore there is no risk to the patient with any surgical procedure.

The device may interpret Electromagnetic Inference (EMI) as a rapid heart rhythm and subsequently record the episode as an inappropriate Tachycardia, but this will be apparent that it is inappropriate when the device is interrogated at the next clinic follow up. Therefore no additional precautions are needed for a patient with an ILR/ICM in situ.

When the need for device reprogramming has been identified, the Device Reprogramming Request Form (Appendix 2) should be fully completed by the responsible anaesthetist/referring consultant/surgeon, including the procedure to be performed, type of diathermy to be used and the TCI date and time.

The patient's CIED follow up centre should be clearly identified on the form and a copy of the patient's last device follow up should be obtained by the preassessment team from the patient's follow up centre and securely attached to the Request Form.

Once all device details have been obtained and the Device Reprogramming Request Form (Appendix 2) is securely attached, fully completed request forms should be returned promptly to Cardiac Centre A210 or emailed to mse.mehtpacingicd@nhs.net to allow adequate time for scheduling of a Cardiac Physiologist to attend on the day of the procedure, and for manufacturer support to be arranged if necessary.
All requests will be date stamped on arrival and added to the waiting list on Tomcat.
**PLEASE ENSURE THAT ALL DEVICE REPROGRAMMING REQUESTS ARE FORMALLY AGREED WITH A CARDIAC PHYSIOLOGIST**
A minimum notice period of 2 Weeks prior to the TCI Date is required for all elective patients on an 18 Week Pathway.
For patients who are on a 62 Day Target, 2 Week Wait or listed for emergency procedures, as much notice as possible is required, ideally where possible a minimum of 2 Weeks.

For any requests that are made at short notice or the Cardiac Physiology Team are not informed in the correct and in a timely manner of procedure date; it may not be guaranteed that a Cardiac Physiologist will be available.
Clinical instruction – pre procedure

The anaesthetist/operating consultant/surgeon is responsible for ensuring the Cardiac Physiology Team are contacted to confirm that the elective procedure is to be performed as planned, with an estimated start time, and has not been cancelled on the day. In the event where an Anaesthetist/Consultant is not present (i.e. Local Anaesthetic only or Registrar Led procedures) then this responsibility lies with the Operator.

If the Date or Time of the TCI is changed it is the responsibility of the waiting list team to ensure the Cardiac Physiology Team are informed of the changes as soon as possible to allow adjustments to be made in order for a Cardiac Physiologist to be available for the new TCI.

If changes are made at short notice or the Cardiac Physiology Team are not informed in a timely manner of the elective procedure, it may not be guaranteed that a Cardiac Physiologist will be available.

It is the responsibility of the Theatre Team to contact the Cardiac Centre (Extension 4209/4185/4458) once the patient has been sent for to the anaesthetic room, and to confirm the theatre number in which the Cardiac Physiologist is required.
A minimum of  minutes notice should ideally be given prior to the patients' arrival to the anaesthetic/procedure room.

Where possible, patients requiring device reprogramming should be placed 1st on the theatre operating list to allow adequate time for device changes to take place within the working hours of the Cardiac Physiology Team, both pre and post procedure.
Prior to Cardiac Physiologist attendance and device reprogramming, all relevant equipment should be available in the anaesthetics room and ready for use, to include:
3 Lead ECG
Pulse Oximeter
External Defibrillator with Pacer Capability
No Anaesthesia or sedating medication should be given until the Cardiac Physiologist is in attendance.
Prior to anaesthesia being given, the External Defibrillator, 3 Lead ECG and Pulse Oximeter should be attached to the patient.

If the patient has an ICD in situ, and shock therapies have been requested to be deactivated, external defibrillation pads should be placed ideally in the Anterior/Posterior position in case of the need for External Transcutaneous Pacing.

data.text: If this is not possible due to the location of surgery, then pads should be placed in a location appropriate to the surgery to allow for an effective defibrillation vector, whilst being at least 15cm away from the CIED to minimise interference and damage to the generator should defibrillation be required. (An example of alternative defibrillation pad placement is shown below).

data.url: 09004 Elective cardiac implantable electronic devices policy 3.2.005.png

data.text: Figure 2: Taken From British Heart Rhythm Society (BHRS) Guidelines  for  the  Management  of  Patients  with  Cardiac Implantable Devices (CIEDs) around the time of surgery (2016/2019)
Clinical instruction – cardiac physiologist
The attending Cardiac Physiologist will explain the procedure and reasoning behind the need for any changes to be made to the CIED and to confirm that the patient is aware and happy to proceed.
The attending Cardiac Physiologist will ensure the current settings/parameters of the device are accurately recorded prior to any changes being made.
Any required changes to the CIED will be made and communicated to the patient and theatre staff, and documented in patient notes, where required.

The attending Cardiac Physiologist is responsible for ensuring correct and accurate documentation, including programmer evidence of any changes that are made to the device on the Cardiology reporting system (TOMCAT), including the attachment of the Request/Consent Form to the patient's file.
Clinical instruction – during procedure

Theatre Staff should closely monitor the patient's haemodynamics throughout the procedure and in the event of a life threatening arrhythmia occurring treat the patient using normal Advanced Life Support (ALS) protocols.

**In the event of a Cardiac Arrest, resuscitation should be undertaken as if there was no CIED present (with exception of defibrillation pad positioning to ensure CIED is protected where reasonably possible)**
There is no risk to performing CPR when a shock is delivered in patients with ICD/CRT-D in situ.
Clinical instruction – post procedure

Once the procedure is complete, the patient must remain attached to the ECG monitoring and external defibrillator with 1:1 nursing care, by a nurse competent to ALS standards until the Cardiac Physiologist has attended and the CIED has been reprogrammed to previous settings.

Once the device has been reprogrammed post procedure, theatre staff may detach any defibrillator pads, external defibrillator and monitoring from the patient, unless required for another specified purpose.
**For those devices that have not been reprogrammed or deactivated for the procedure, no post procedure device check is required unless adverse events have occurred**

The attending Cardiac Physiologist will document any changes made to the device on the Cardiology reporting system (TOMCAT) and in patient's notes, where required, including evidence of any device parameters changed pre and post procedure
Emergency ‘out of hours' CIED reprogramming
There are situations where emergency device reprogramming is required outside of normal working hours of the Cardiac Physiology Team (9-5pm Monday to Friday).
If deactivation by a Cardiac Physiologist is not available, for emergency procedures only, a magnet can be applied directly over the generator site.
**Magnets should not be used as an alternative to formal device reprogramming/deactivation for elective surgical procedures**

Medical staff should obtain verbal consent where possible for magnet use. This should ideally by done following communication to the patient (if appropriate) and/or the Next of Kin/family (if deemed necessary). A full explanation of the reasons for the use of a magnet including the potential consequences should be discussed prior to use.
**The response to the presence of a magnet in both pacemakers and ICDs is only temporary and normal function will resume as soon as the magnet is removed**
Behaviour of CIED's in Response to Magnet Application:

Pacemakers respond to magnet application with fixed rate (asynchronous) pacing. While this can be beneficial in rare situations where pacing is inhibited by diathermy, leaving a magnet over the pacemaker is not generally recommended. The asynchronous pacing can occasionally be arrhythmogenic (R on T phenomenon); therefore magnet therapy is generally only recommended for patients who are dependent on their pacemakers.
ICDs respond to magnet application with the inhibition of anti-tachycardia pacing and shock therapy.
**Magnet application has no effect on bradycardia pacing in ICDs**
Magnet Application for ICD:
There are two main types of ICD; Transvenous and Subcutaneous.
Please see the following diagram to aid in correctly identifying the type of ICD in situ and subsequently how to correctly apply a magnet if necessary.

data.url: 09004 Elective cardiac implantable electronic devices policy 3.2.006.jpeg
09004 Elective cardiac implantable electronic devices policy 3.2.007.png

data.text: **Some devices are only inhibited by a magnet for 8 hours; If the surgery is to be prolonged (>8 Hours), the magnet should be removed for 30 seconds (in which the device will reactivate) and be reapplied every 7 Hours**
Magnets can be obtained from the following locations:
Cardiac Centre (A210)
Theatres – Theatre 2 Anaesthetic Room (Located on the CD Cupboard)
Acute Medical Unit (A204) – (Located in the CD Cupboard)
Palliative Care Nurses (Community)
Trigger Response Team (Located in their Grab Bag)
Hospital Out of Hours Office
Farleigh Hospice
Infection Prevention

All staff will adhere to Trust guidelines on infection prevention at all times; such as hand washing, the use of sterile procedures, and additional infection prevention measures when required i.e. gloves and aprons and effective decontamination of all non-disposable equipment between patients.
Monitoring and Audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: INTENDED PROCEDURE: **Please include site of surgery and clearly state procedure to be performed**
DATE OF LAST FOLLOW UP **Please obtain and attach a copy of last follow-up report to this request form before submission**

I confirm that the following has been discussed with the patient and/or family: The need and consequences for the device to be reprogrammed before and after the procedure (this may include temporary deactivation of shock therapy). The reassurance that the patient will be appropriately monitored throughout the procedure to ensure patient safety (this may include constant monitoring via external defibrillator). Patient and/or next of kin consent has been obtained.

I confirm that the above points have been discussed and fully explained to me as the patient/next of kin/power of attorney and I am happy for device reprogramming/deactivation to be performed in order for my procedure to be undertaken safely.

What are you proposing to change?
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Due for Trust Review – last review September 2017 Update Details within policy due to changes in email addresses within the trust
Who benefits from this change and how?

All elective surgical patients with CIED's implanted – process has been updated in line with updated British Heart Rhythm Society (BHRS) Guidelines. Update of process and policy will clarify how to manage patients of this nature when they are to be preassessed and admitted for elective surgical procedures.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?

data.text: If you have identified any negative impact in the preliminary analysis above, please request and complete the full Equality Impact Assessment (EIA) from Document Control.
